unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Unemployment Concerns
question_text:
The threat of unemployment is a major concern for working adults.
In a survey of $1{,}500\text{ working adults}$, $720\text{ men}$ and $780\text{ women}$ were asked the question, “Are you concerned about losing your job within the next $12\text{ months}$?”
Of those who were surveyed, $312\text{ males}$ said “yes,” and $240\text{ females}$ said “yes.”
Why would it be considered incorrect to use a one-proportion $Z$-interval in this situation?

choices.text: It is not known if the sampling distribution is approximately normal.
The data compares two independent proportions.

solution:
There are two independent populations we are examining in this situation (men and women), so a two-proportion $z$-interval is more appropriate.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; this problem deals with proportions, which never follow the $T$ distribution.

Choice 'B' is incorrect; since $np$ and $n(1-p)$ are both well over $10$, the sampling distribution will be approximately normal.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; standard deviation can be found using the following formula:

$$\sqrt { \dfrac { { p }_{ 1 }(1-{ p }_{ 1 }) }{ { n }_{ 1 } } +\dfrac { { p_{ 2 }(1- }{ p }_{ 2 }) }{ { n }_{ 2 } } } $$

In this case, the first samples proportion:

$${ p }_{ 1 }= \dfrac { 312 }{ 720 } = 0.433$$

The second sample proportion:

$${ n }_{ 2 }=\dfrac { 240 }{ 780 } =0.308$$

Sample sizes ${ n }_{ 1 }$ and ${ n }_{ 2 }$ are $720$ and $780$, respectively.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; there is no information in the problem that suggests that bias occurs.
